commit_message:
introduce plugin loading

This patch introduces the notion of plugin loading including the ability
to populate a neutron_lib.plugins.directory. The functionality herein
is based off the plugin loading code in neutron.manager.NeutronManager.
However rather than rehoming the NeutronManager as-is this patch takes a
new modular approach given:
- The work done in [1] moves neutron's plugin "cache" to the directory
module in neutron_lib.
- The basic functionality of NeutronManager can be broken down into:
-- Loading the core plugin + services as well as the default and conf
specified service plugins and adding them all to the plugin directory.
This functionality is included herein.
-- Acting as a singleton structure to store pecan controllers/resources.
This functionality is not included herein and is left for future work
as the caching of pecan artifacts seems orthogonal.

The high level approach taken in this patch for plugin loading is:
- Provide a generic set of "loading" functionality including a generic
loader capable of loading plugins from a given conf and processing
pre/post validation. This functionality provides default capabilities to
load neutron core/default services/plugins as well as the ability to
load from non-default's in the future. See loader.py.
- Functionality in directory.py to use loaders to populate the directory
with plugins. Consumers can use these public functions to initialize
the plugin env.
- Use the service definitions introduced in [2] to determine default
services, lookup services for an api, etc.

[1] I7331e914234c5f0b7abe836604fdd7e4067551cf
[2] If9ccb0cf145aca4a7f051ce7c461b19936d3d25a

Partially-implements: blueprint neutron-lib-networking-ovn

Change-Id: I263a56ed024455644d3be1fadad5900fe67f033a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/43/456343/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_utils import excutils from neutron_lib._i18n import _ from neutron_lib.services import definitions as services from neutron_lib.utils import runtime LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CORE_PLUGINS_NAMESPACE = 'neutron.core_plugins' SERVICE_PLUGINS_NAMESPACE = 'neutron.service_plugins' CONF_OPT_CORE_PLUGIN = 'core_plugin' CONF_OPT_SERVICE_PLUGINS = 'service_plugins' def load_plugin_class(namespace, entry_point): try: return runtime.load_class_by_alias_or_classname( namespace, entry_point) except ImportError: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.error("Plugin '%s' not found.", entry_point) def load_plugin_instance(namespace, entry_point): return load_plugin_class(namespace, entry_point)() def find_services_for_plugin(plugin): supported_services = [] for ext_alias in getattr(plugin, "supported_extension_aliases", []): service = services.service_for_api_alias(ext_alias) if service: supported_services.append(service) return supported_services def load_default_service_plugins(namespace=SERVICE_PLUGINS_NAMESPACE): default_plugin_names = [ s.ENTRY_POINT_NAME for s in services.default_services()] return [load_plugin_instance(namespace, n) for n in default_plugin_names] def propagate_agent_notifiers(from_plugin, to_plugin): if (hasattr(to_plugin, 'agent_notifiers') and hasattr(from_plugin, 'agent_notifiers')): to_plugin.agent_notifiers.update(from_plugin.agent_notifiers) def validate_conf_opt_defined(loader): opt_name = loader.opt_name conf = loader.conf if opt_name not in conf or conf[opt_name] is None: return _("Configuration option '%s' is not defined.") % opt_name def validate_dhcp_agents_per_network(loader): if ('dhcp_agents_per_network' in loader.conf and loader.conf.dhcp_agents_per_network <= 0): return _("dhcp_agents_per_network must be >= 1. '%s' " "is invalid.") % loader.conf.dhcp_agents_per_network class ConfPluginLoader(object): def __init__(self, conf=None, plugin_opt_name=None, namespace=None, preload_validators=None, postload_validators=None): self.conf = conf or cfg.CONF self.default_opt_name = plugin_opt_name self.opt_name = None self.default_namespace = namespace self.namespace = None self.preload_validators = preload_validators or [] self.postload_validators = postload_validators or [] def load(self, plugin_opt_name=None, namespace=None): self.opt_name = plugin_opt_name or self.default_opt_name self.namespace = namespace or self.default_namespace self._run_validators(self.preload_validators) plugin_names = self.conf[self.opt_name] if not isinstance(plugin_names, list): plugin_names = [plugin_names] LOG.debug("Loading config option '%s' plugins: %s", (self.opt_name, plugin_names)) plugins = [] for plugin_name in plugin_names: if plugin_name == '': continue LOG.info("Loading plugin '%s' for namespace: %s", (plugin_name, self.namespace)) plugins.append(load_plugin_instance(self.namespace, plugin_name)) self._run_validators(self.postload_validators) return plugins def _run_validators(self, validators): for validate in validators: error_msg = validate(self) if error_msg: LOG.critical(error_msg) raise Exception(error_msg) def new_core_plugin_loader(**loader_kwargs): default_kwargs = { 'plugin_opt_name': CONF_OPT_CORE_PLUGIN, 'namespace': CORE_PLUGINS_NAMESPACE, 'preload_validators': [validate_conf_opt_defined], 'postload_validators': [validate_dhcp_agents_per_network] } default_kwargs.update(loader_kwargs) return ConfPluginLoader(**default_kwargs) def new_service_plugin_loader(**loader_kwargs): default_kwargs = { 'plugin_opt-Name': CONF_OPT_SERVICE_PLUGINS, 'namespace': SERVICE_PLUGINS_NAMESPACE } default_kwargs.update(loader_kwargs) return ConfPluginLoader(**default_kwargs)

commit_message:
Add check for quering neutron core resources with standardattr sort-key

This patch add the check in get_and_validate_sort_keys function. When user
query network/port or some other core resources which inherited from
HasStandardAttributes. And input sort-keys like created_at/description.
We can let them pass into following process.

Change-Id: Icfeab12b2317e3d186e0ce585a5de08b8d5b0bc7
Partial-Bug: #1659175
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/48/424948/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Introduce service definitions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-10 21:10:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/47f9b45c1b035a5cd2d8cfeec1917f6c91de4475', 'message': 'Introduce service definitions

This patch introduces the notion of service definitions that look
very similar to API definitions. Subsequent patches will build on
these definitions; for example loading plugin behavior of neutron
manager.

Partially implements: neutron-lib-networking-ovn

Change-Id: If9ccb0cf145aca4a7f051ce7c461b19936d3d25a
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-04-25 15:44:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/dd2589eff22a8286ac1894bc490af40d09f25e66', 'message': 'Introduce service definitions

Neutron's notion of services (service plugins) includes not only the
backing code to implement extension(s), but also service specific static
metadata. For example:
- A plugin type and description as defined by the ServicePluginBase
interface [1].
- A collection of supported_extension_aliases [1] that define which
API extensions the service plugin implements. NB: these are now becoming
neutron_lib.api.definitions, so we can think of them as such in this
context.
- A stevedore entry-point name. While this is defined in setup.cfg of
neutron, the entry-point name is used in a number of cases in neutron.
For example in the DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS of neutron [2].
- A set of "default" service plugins [2]; DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS.
- A mapping from extension alias to service plugin type [2] via
EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING.
- A set of well known service types as defined as constants in [2].

This patch proposes we take an approach to defining that static aspects
of services in neutron-lib, similar to what we did in
neutron_lib.api.definitions for API extensions. By doing so we can
consolidate where services define this static data, and do away with
the global approach of managing EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING,
DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS, etc. in addition to the type and description
returned by the service plugin [1]. This approach also allows us to
build a simple set of APIs atop the service definitions that can be
used at runtime. For example when loading and binding plugin instances
to service definitions [3].

For an example of how these definitions map into neutron, please see
the neutron_lib.services.definitions._dummy module's comments.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/services/base.py#L52
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/common/constants.py
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/456343/1/neutron_lib/plugins/loader.py@48

Partially implements: neutron-lib-networking-ovn

Change-Id: If9ccb0cf145aca4a7f051ce7c461b19936d3d25a
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-05-02 17:04:26.000000000', 'files': ['neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/__init__.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/auto_allocate.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/flavors.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/l3.py', 'neutron_lib/api/definitions/base.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_segments.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_l3.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/metering.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_metering.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_auto_allocate.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/tag.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_loki.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_revisions.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/revisions.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/trunk.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/__init__.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/base.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_qos.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/network_ip_availability.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_network_ip_availability.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_trunk.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_tag.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_flavors.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/_dummy.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/loki.py', 'neutron_lib/tests/unit/services/definitions/test_timestamp.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/qos.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/timestamp.py', 'neutron_lib/services/definitions/segments.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/9357baba058b0338ca26ef958b41c5af5c072251', 'message': 'Introduce service definitions

Forward/motivation:
Today, metadata about neutron services (service plugins) is leveraged
in a number of ways by consumers. For example:
- Well known service type constants [2] are used by consumers
implementing and/or introspecting neutron service plugins. For
example LOADBALANCER [4].
- Interfacing with the EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING [5].
- Accessing service constants. For example QoS [6].

In addition, there maybe some areas for potential improvement in this
space including:
- More explicitly defining the default services that are today defined
in DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS [2].
- Explicitly linking a service definition to the API definitions it
supports.
- Leveraging some of the same techniques we did with neutron-lib API
defs that leverage the service metadata and define a base interface
so concrete service implementations don't have to implement this
common behavior.

This patch takes the first step in standardizing service definitions
that are static metadata about a particular service. It also
begins to provide a simple set of APIs across the definitions
including leveraging the linking between a service definition and
its respective api-def(s) supported.

Implementation details:
Neutron's notion of services (service plugins) includes not only the
backing code to implement extension(s), but also service specific static
metadata. For example:
- A plugin type and description as defined by the ServicePluginBase
interface [1].
- A collection of supported_extension_aliases [1] that define which
API extensions the service plugin implements. NB: these are now becoming
neutron_lib.api.definitions, so we can think of them as such in this
context.
- A stevedore entry-point name. While this is defined in setup.cfg of
neutron, the entry-point name is used in a number of cases in neutron.
For example in the DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS of neutron [2].
- A set of "default" service plugins [2]; DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS.
- A mapping from extension alias to service plugin type [2] via
EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING.
- A set of well known service types as defined as constants in [2].

This patch proposes we take an approach to defining that static aspects
of services in neutron-lib, similar to what we did in
neutron_lib.api.definitions for API extensions. By doing so we can
consolidate where services define this static data, and do away with
the global approach of managing EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING,
DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS, etc. in addition to the type and description
returned by the service plugin [1]. This approach also allows us to
build a simple set of APIs atop the service definitions that can be
used at runtime. For example when loading and binding plugin instances
to service definitions [3].

For an example of how these definitions map into neutron, please see
the neutron_lib.services.definitions._dummy module's comments.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/services/base.py#L52
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/common/constants.py
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/456343/1/neutron_lib/plugins/loader.py@48
[4] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=%5C.LOADBALANCER
[5] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=%5C.EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING
[6] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20neutron%5C.services%5C.qos%20import%20qos_consts

Partially implements: neutron-lib-networking-ovn

Change-Id: If9ccb0cf145aca4a7f051ce7c461b19936d3d25a
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce service definitions

Forward/motivation:
Today, metadata about neutron services (service plugins) is leveraged
in a number of ways by consumers. For example:
- Well known service type constants [2] are used by consumers
implementing and/or introspecting neutron service plugins. For
example LOADBALANCER [4].
- Interfacing with the EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING [5].
- Accessing service constants. For example QoS [6].

In addition, there maybe some areas for potential improvement in this
space including:
- More explicitly defining the default services that are today defined
in DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS [2].
- Explicitly linking a service definition to the API definitions it
supports.
- Leveraging some of the same techniques we did with neutron-lib API
defs that leverage the service metadata and define a base interface
so concrete service implementations don't have to implement this
common behavior.

This patch takes the first step in standardizing service definitions
that are static metadata about a particular service. It also
begins to provide a simple set of APIs across the definitions
including leveraging the linking between a service definition and
its respective api-def(s) supported.

Implementation details:
Neutron's notion of services (service plugins) includes not only the
backing code to implement extension(s), but also service specific static
metadata. For example:
- A plugin type and description as defined by the ServicePluginBase
interface [1].
- A collection of supported_extension_aliases [1] that define which
API extensions the service plugin implements. NB: these are now becoming
neutron_lib.api.definitions, so we can think of them as such in this
context.
- A stevedore entry-point name. While this is defined in setup.cfg of
neutron, the entry-point name is used in a number of cases in neutron.
For example in the DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS of neutron [2].
- A set of "default" service plugins [2]; DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS.
- A mapping from extension alias to service plugin type [2] via
EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING.
- A set of well known service types as defined as constants in [2].

This patch proposes we take an approach to defining that static aspects
of services in neutron-lib, similar to what we did in
neutron_lib.api.definitions for API extensions. By doing so we can
consolidate where services define this static data, and do away with
the global approach of managing EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING,
DEFAULT_SERVICE_PLUGINS, etc. in addition to the type and description
returned by the service plugin [1]. This approach also allows us to
build a simple set of APIs atop the service definitions that can be
used at runtime. For example when loading and binding plugin instances
to service definitions [3].

For an example of how these definitions map into neutron, please see
the neutron_lib.services.definitions._dummy module's comments.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/services/base.py#L52
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/common/constants.py
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/456343/1/neutron_lib/plugins/loader.py@48
[4] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=%5C.LOADBALANCER
[5] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=%5C.EXT_TO_SERVICE_MAPPING
[6] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20neutron%5C.services%5C.qos%20import%20qos_consts

Partially implements: neutron-lib-networking-ovn

Change-Id: If9ccb0cf145aca4a7f051ce7c461b19936d3d25a

commit_message:
Rehome quotasv2 and quotasv2_detail api-def

This patch rehomes neutron's quota api definitions into
neutron-lib.

Change-Id: Ic3624ccb562e293b470a1c4943bfc6599d276082
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/36/444536/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # The name of the resource. RESOURCE_NAME = 'quota' # The plural for the resource. RESOURCE_COLLECTION = 'quotas' # The alias of the extension. ALIAS = 'quotas' # The label to lookup the plugin in the plugin directory. It can match the # alias, as required. LABEL = 'quotas' # Whether or not this extension is simply signaling behavior to the user # or it actively modifies the attribute map. IS_SHIM_EXTENSION = False # Whether the extension is marking the adoption of standardattr model for # legacy resources, or introducing new standardattr attributes. False or # None if the standardattr model is adopted since the introduction of # resource extension. # If this is True, the alias for the extension should be prefixed with # 'standard-attr-'. IS_STANDARD_ATTR_EXTENSION = False # The name of the extension. NAME = 'Quota management support' # A prefix for API resources. An empty prefix means that the API is going # to be exposed at the v2/ level as any other core resource. API_PREFIX = '' # The description of the extension. DESCRIPTION = "Expose functions for quotas management" # A timestamp of when the extension was introduced. UPDATED_TIMESTAMP = "2012-07-29T10:00:00-00:00" RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = { RESOURCE_COLLECTION: {} } DEFAULT_QUOTAS_ACTION = 'default' MEMBER_ACTIONS = {DEFAULT_QUOTAS_ACTION: 'GET'} COLLECTION_ACTIONS = {'tenant': 'GET'} # The subresource attribute map for the extension. It adds child resources # to main extension's resource. The subresource map must have a parent and # a parameters entry. If an extension does not need such a map, None can # be specified (mandatory). SUB_RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = None # The action map: it associates verbs with methods to be performed on # the API resource. ACTION_MAP = {} # The list of required extensions. REQUIRED_EXTENSIONS = [] # The list of optional extensions. OPTIONAL_EXTENSIONS = []

dynamically via BGP' UPDATED_TIMESTAMP = '2016-05-10T15:37:00-00:00' RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP = { BGP_SPEAKER_RESOURCE_NAME + 's': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': db_const.NAME_FIELD_SIZE}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': True}, 'advertise_tenant_networks': { 'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'convert_to': n_conv.convert_to_boolean, 'validate': {'type:boolean': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': True, 'required_by_policy': False, 'enforce_policy': True}, }, 'bgp-peers': { 'id': {'allow_post': False, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:uuid': None}, 'is_visible': True, 'primary_key': True}, 'name': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'validate': {'type:string': db_const.NAME_FIELD_SIZE}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': ''}, 'peer_ip': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'required_by_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:ip_address': None}, 'is_visible': True}, 'remote_as': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'validate': {'type:range': (bgp_consts.MIN_ASNUM, bgp_consts.MAX_ASNUM)}, 'is_visible': True, 'default': None, 'required_by_policy': False, 'enforce_policy': False}, 'auth_type': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'required_by_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:values': bgp_consts.SUPPORTED_AUTH_TYPES}, 'is_visible': True}, 'password': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'required_by_policy': True, 'validate': {'type:string_or_none': None}, 'is_visible': False, 'default': None}, 'tenant_id': {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False, 'required_by_policy': False, 'validate': { 'type:string': db_const.PROJECT_ID_FIELD_SIZE}, 'is_visible': True} } } # The action map. ACTION_MAP = { BGP_SPEAKER_RESOURCE_NAME: { 'add_bgp_peer': 'PUT', 'remove_bgp_peer': 'PUT', 'add_gateway_network': 'PUT', 'remove_gateway_network': 'PUT', 'get_advertised_routes': 'GET' } } # The list of required extensions. commit_message:
Stop using deprecated 'message' attribute in Exception

The 'message' attribute has been deprecated and removed
from Python3.
For more details, please check:
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0352/

Change-Id: Ia304170faa6d3a6cec63b8f874101db7559176e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate-dashboard refs/changes/21/475621/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ex is not None: data['message'] = ex
deleted_lines: if ex.message is not None: data['message'] = ex.message

commit_message:
Migrate Neutron QoS extension definitions to neutron-lib

This is the first patch to migrate the QoS API definitions from
Neutron to neutron-lib. Once it is merged, all projects using QoS
extension will be migrated to use this library.

Change-Id: Id4517bc9947845390eec23c591b6fbcede7850b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/83/452883/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Allow setting copied files group more precisely

Previously with the config_files structure of config.json, the group
name was automatically set to the one of the user name. It is now
possible to set the group name in the same fashion than the
'permissions' structure with:

  owner: 'desired_owner:desired_group'

Closes-Bug: #1696095
Change-Id: Ibae9f74e2351c81a717294467aedc51ea773c41e

commit_message:
nova/neutron format integration is failed

Modify designate-sink formatv4/v6 parameter "project".
"tenant" key is not contain at "context" variable,
so I use "project_name" key.
And "context" dict object cannot use getattr function.

Change-Id: If485766a928bc2143b0b15afe99af38a6f927239
Closes-Bug: #1655581
(cherry picked from commit b23cae7b7839af2d2ed38c06a126f1e2a869ddd3)

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary setUp function in testcase

In testcase, setUp will be called automatically. This patch used to
remove setUp functions that do nothing. Besides, it will keep code clean.

commit_message:
Fix missing format of impl_infoblox config file

- The 'deprecated_reason' will created if 'deprecated_for_removal=True'
and help='DEPRECATED: <string>'.
- Currently format will be raising 'NoneType' object if we want
to genconfig testenv(in-progress [1]).

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/472770/

Change-Id: I1b542175cb471093787e0ba0947bc5920917f29b

commit_message:
Fix UUID and String value in test_pool

- Pool_id must be UUID value, it's not an integer.
- target_id must be UUID value [1].
- namserver_id must be UUID value [2].
- 'options' value of targets must be String format [3].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/designate/blob/master/designate/objects/pool_target.py#L25
[2] https://github.com/openstack/designate/blob/master/designate/objects/pool_nameserver.py#L25
[3] https://github.com/openstack/designate/blob/master/designate/objects/pool_target_option.py#L37

Change-Id: Ibd616470233747a7aab9fe04ebf5fcfa0a59fd22
Co-authored-By: Dai Dang Van <daidv@vn.fujitsu.com>

commit_message:
Improving check warning build_sphinx

- With this PS, we could be received a warning error at same time
when build sphinx decumentation of Designate via:

    $ python setup.py build_sphinx

- Fix some issues with docs sphinx.

Change-Id: I1e5a8c4b45dc3d10028531eabb50d3d6189ea070

commit_message:
Return PoolList as a right list object

- We are using PoolAttributeList object for this case
and put a list of Pool objects for it.

Co-authored-By: Nguyen Van Trung <trungnv@vn.fujitsu.com>

commit_message:
Disable swift middleware ceilometer pipeline by default

This generates tons of unnecessary events when gnocchi uses swift backend.
We end up filtering most of these anyway. So lets disable this so it
doesn't put useless load. Also changing the default project to service as
thats what gnocchi uses to authenticate with swift.

Closes-bug: #1693339

Change-Id: I40f47d46fdb06f31a739b590bf653bca71e33f61

commit_message:
place holder environment config for toci and quickstart

Before environment config is formally used in toci, a
no-op place holder is required so toci does not run
with the default libvirt settings in [1].
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/469992/

Change-Id: I25ed3361f8ffbef92adc44d9dd04906d9658641b

commit_message:
Fix playbook syntax in base post playbook

Er, plays aren't separated by documents.  A playbook is a list
of plays.

Change-Id: I55fb2823f52547480fdcbca0bf8130f844012c82

commit_message:
Improve testcase

We should have better inputs for objects that we created
even when we don't face with wrong inputs because
we didn't call validate() for each time we set attribute.

- Fix some wrong UUID into correctly value.

Co-authored-By: Nguyen Van Trung <trungnv@vn.fujitsu.com>

Change-Id: Ibe0e24e6cc0366deb2b669ade2c9ff87f7eebe4e

commit_message:
Remove .testrepository/times.dbm

When we run tox command, we are facing with
test fail problem like: "No module named gdbm".
This patch adds cleaning up of this file
before running next tests.

Change-Id: If906d8c684cce14b62dec718fd22b6903b0ac663

commit_message:
Ensure TTL is not 0 for zone imports

If zone imports have a ttl of 0 update
the zone ttl to the min_ttl configured for
the designate install

Change-Id: Idec854997fa9b6ad5d6af29bf6935c069dcbc40a
Closes-Bug: #1586178

commit_message:
Rework TOP_DIR logic

Currently, we use a simple logic for the client scripts to find
libraries, configuration files, etc. We know they will be copied to the
autostart directory from where TOP_DIR is one step up. If a user ever
tried to run a script in its original location (e.g. in scripts/ubuntu),
this logic would fail.

This has been a theoretical problem as long as users just used osbash.sh
or st.py to run the scripts. But if users would like to run extra
scripts, logging in to the nodes and running the scripts where they
find them would be the most natural way to do it.

Right now, the main use case is the heat service which is not installed
by default but can be installed at a later time if so desired -- with
the gotcha described above.

As more services are becoming optional add-ons to the install-guide,
this becomes an issue.

This patch installs a new logic: if a script finds a file named
TOP_DIR in its parent dir, it will use the file's contents as a
pointer to the TOP_DIR location.

TOP_DIR is a file rather than a symlink because the file needs to
work on Windows file systems as well.

The file lives in the parent directory rather than the script directory
because that reduces the number of such files that are required. This
becomes more relevant once we store additional services along with their
supporting files in extras/<service_name>/.

Change-Id: Ib0ccb108e5246ff8e06d87730ce11704d719fb75

commit_message:
fix the autodoc instructions

Use autodoc_index_modules instead of autodoc_tree_index_modules so only
one copy of the API docs are generated.

Exclude the tests subpackage because it's not part of the Glance Python
API.

Exclude the glance.db.sqlalchemy subpackage to avoid issues caused when
parts of it cannot be imported during the doc build because they rely on
alembic setting up values that are not configured for a simple import.

Change-Id: I127b812bc879fc39533b39df1785d93835142430
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
rearrange existing documentation to follow the new layout standard

This change moves existing files, updates a few of the cross-references
and paths, and fixes some formatting. It is not meant to be the final
word on how the main page looks or how the other files are organized,
but it gets everything roughly into shape. If the glance team wants to
make changes, please do those as follow-up patches

This change depends on the spec and on a feature of pbr that allows us
to move where the auto-generated class reference documentation ends up
in the tree.

Depends-On: Ia750cb049c0f53a234ea70ce1f2bbbb7a2aa9454
Depends-On: I2bd5652bb59cbd9c939931ba2e7db1b37d2b30bb
Change-Id: I9dde267793a5913acb5b1ec028cfb66bc5189783
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
tasks: tempest_install: Simplify distro package installation

Use the 'package' Ansible module to simplify the distribution
package installation instead of having separate playbooks per package
manager. Moreover, avoid the loop by passing the package list directly
to the module

Change-Id: Ie3e3e8bec057ee07acacc8733a1984fbe168b7cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest refs/changes/91/478491/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add manager resource

This patch adds the Manager/ManagerCollection resource. Manager
resource will provide information about remote access controls like
serial console, command shell, graphical console etc. It will also
serve as the gateway to virtual media, ethernet interfaces (NICs)
information.
'ResetActionField' moved to a new file, "resources/common.py",
to be reused both by system and manager resource. Necessary changes
are also made to the usage documentation page pertaining to Manager
resource.

Partial-Bug: #1673886
Change-Id: I1d1b9b3f13002e654e4dc62d0558f5a2afbd8662

commit_message:
Remove telemetry roles from role requirements

The telemetry roles are under-maintained, and not properly tested.
Hence, the roles are removed as a requirement  from OpenStack-Ansible
until they can find a maintainer.

The telemetry code(tasks, variables, etc.) will be kept in the
integrated repo.

Change-Id: I0de73859608e0c4538b17429878b177e7276b095

deleted_lines: class CheckForAssertingNoneEquality(BaseASTChecker): """Ensure that code does not use a None with assert(Not*)Equal.""" CHECK_DESC_IS = ('K003 Use self.assertIsNone(...) when comparing ' 'against None') CHECK_DESC_ISNOT = ('K004 Use assertIsNotNone(...) when comparing ' ' against None') def visit_Call(self, node): # NOTE(dstanek): I wrote this in a verbose way to make it easier to # read for those that have little experience with Python's AST. def _is_None(node): if six.PY3: return (isinstance(node, ast.NameConstant) and node.value is None) else: return isinstance(node, ast.Name) and node.id == 'None' if isinstance(node.func, ast.Attribute): if node.func.attr == 'assertEqual': for arg in node.args: if _is_None(arg): self.add_error(node, message=self.CHECK_DESC_IS) elif node.func.attr == 'assertNotEqual': for arg in node.args: if _is_None(arg): self.add_error(node, message=self.CHECK_DESC_ISNOT) super(CheckForAssertingNoneEquality, self).generic_visit(node) register(CheckForAssertingNoneEquality)

commit_message:
Replace the usage of 'manager' with 'os_primary'

In tempest, alias 'manager' has been moved to 'os_primary'
in version Pike, and it will be removed in version Queens.
This patch is to replace the usage of 'manager' with 'os_primary'.

For other details, please check [1] and [2]
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/468036/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/463484/

Change-Id: Ie2ed78ed2b382a83d9ad2adcade864358037ae5e

commit_message:
[upstream] Move Branching Model to Archive

It was intended that this be moved to the archive since we
haven't used it in the latest training. We cover some discussion
of stable branches elsewhere so it's not necessary to have a whole
slide deck in the agenda that we don't cover anyway.

Change-Id: I38d70709e8cd36688bc2a55741263d093f4b3e47

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-27 14:28:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-win/commit/84cb9ab135b75831d6ce417ccccdee64bd7efd36', 'message': 'Handle transient vm snapshot errors

We had a considerable amount of transient errors when taking vm
snapshots.

We're usually getting "vendor reserved" job status codes for which
we can't be sure if the snapshot actually gets created or not.

This change will retry taking vm snapshots in case of failures. In
case of job states handled as errors, we're checking if the expected
snapshot exists, in which case we treat it as a success.

Change-Id: I93a8657de3c1200d5b6987e8ae02ced98ca0068f
Partial-Bug: #1694661
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-28 11:40:27.000000000', 'files': ['os_win/tests/unit/utils/compute/test_vmutils.py', 'os_win/utils/compute/vmutils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-win/commit/d6d973aac135d56715b141de1209a3248f2cb025', 'message': 'Handle transient vm snapshot errors

We had a considerable amount of transient errors when taking vm
snapshots.

Usually we're getting a 32768 job status code. Although this is
not mentioned in the MS docs, it is defined in the Powershell
modules as "CompletedWithWarnings". Instead of erroring out,
we're now checking if the requested snapshot was actually
created, in which case we treat it as a successful operation.

Change-Id: I93a8657de3c1200d5b6987e8ae02ced98ca0068f
Partial-Bug: #1694661
'}]
commit_message:
Handle transient vm snapshot errors

We had a considerable amount of transient errors when taking vm
snapshots.

Usually we're getting a 32768 job status code. Although this is
not mentioned in the MS docs, it is defined in the Powershell
modules as "CompletedWithWarnings". Instead of erroring out,
we're now checking if the requested snapshot was actually
created, in which case we treat it as a successful operation.

Change-Id: I93a8657de3c1200d5b6987e8ae02ced98ca0068f
Partial-Bug: #1694661

The MS docs # imply that this can be called in a syncronous way but do not mention # the required flags. try: job = self._jobutils.check_ret_val(ret_val, job_path) snp_setting_data = get_snp_from_job(job) except exceptions.WMIJobFailed as ex: # We had a considerable amount of transient errors when taking # vm snapshots (bug #1694661). LOG.exception("Failed to retrieve VM snapshot after " "unexpected job status code.") else: ctxt.reraise = False LOG.warning("VM snapshot successfuly created after " "unexpected exception: %s.", ex)

subject: Resolve unorderable types errors
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-28 16:05:12.000000000', 'files': ['lookup/py_pkgs.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins/commit/8685a0ba38b7f534dd4db971da6d54b495c79169', 'message': "Resolve unorderable types errors

Python 3 raises errors when attempting to compare types that don't have
a meaningful natural ordering.

If a processed file does not belong to a role it's not neccessary to
create a mapping of a project_group for a `None` role, to prevent
'None' from being compared to other string role names within the
'role_project_groups' dict.

For variables containing lists of dictionaries, like
'remote_package_parts', sort using the 'name' property of each
dictionary.

Change-Id: I9ec4b0b3b7236450f19c1d6186eb310fb7f1e083
Implements: blueprint goal-python35
"}]
commit_message:
Resolve unorderable types errors

Python 3 raises errors when attempting to compare types that don't have
a meaningful natural ordering.

If a processed file does not belong to a role it's not neccessary to
create a mapping of a project_group for a `None` role, to prevent
'None' from being compared to other string role names within the
'role_project_groups' dict.

For variables containing lists of dictionaries, like
'remote_package_parts', sort using the 'name' property of each
dictionary.

Change-Id: I9ec4b0b3b7236450f19c1d6186eb310fb7f1e083
Implements: blueprint goal-python35
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins refs/changes/44/478544/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Wrap "WMI not found" exception

There are situations in which a VM unexpectedly disappears while
we're trying to perform an operation on it. Raising an appropriate
os-win exception in such cases helps os-win consumers perform
appropriate error handling.

This change adapts the decorator translating such exceptions,
using it for the 'get_vm_summary_info' method. This will help Nova
properly handle the case in which an instance is deleted while an
instance lifecycle event is checked.

Related-Bug: #1653862

Change-Id: I6930ed9df9a79e4f8f01bb96ce6dd942fd4760f8

added_lines: def not_found_decorator(translated_exc=exceptions.NotFound): def wrapper(func): def inner(*args, **kwargs): try: return func(*args, **kwargs) except exceptions.x_wmi as ex: if _is_not_found_exc(ex): LOG.debug('x_wmi: Not Found exception raised while ' 'running %s', func.__name__) raise translated_exc(message=six.text_type(ex)) raise return inner return wrapper
deleted_lines: def not_found_decorator(func): def inner(*args, **kwargs): try: return func(*args, **kwargs) except exceptions.x_wmi as ex: if _is_not_found_exc(ex): LOG.debug('x_wmi: Not Found exception raised while ' 'running %s', func.__name__) raise exceptions.NotFound(six.text_type(ex)) raise return inner

subject: Cache attributes with custom handling
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-03 21:06:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/a64d63df05803516f9ef2523ad82041b590e4d11', 'message': 'Add cached attr decorator to template_resource

This commit:
1) Creates the cache_get_attribute decorator to take advantange of the
    caching and storage of attributes that already work with "normal"
    resources.
2) Uses the above decorator to wrap TemplateResource.get_attribute.

Now, template resource attributes (AKA nested stack outputs) are
stored just as typical resource attributes when
resource.store_attributes() is called, and are loaded as cached
attributes (if they exist) in resource._load_data().

The big win is: when a parent stack resolves the output of a nested
stack, the nested stack need not be loaded if the stack output is
already available as a cached resource attribute (typically the case
for a CREATE_COMPLETE stack resource).

Change-Id: I07ac22cc4370a79bd8712e2431fa3272115bc0eb
Closes-Bug: #1660831

'}, {'number': 23, 'created': '2017-06-22 00:22:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/214556ce4e77cdee232c9822dc0dc6db99838f1d', 'message': "Cache attributes with custom handling

Previously, all caching of attribute values was done via the Attributes
object. However, some resource types override Resource.get_attribute() to
do custom handling of the trailing attribute path or dynamic attribute
names, and in these cases the resulting values were not cached (since they
don't go through the Attributes object).

This patch adds a caching step for these resources:

* OS::Senlin::Cluster
* OS::Heat::ResourceChain
* OS::Heat::ResourceGroup
* OS::Heat::AutoscalingGroup
* OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment
* OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup
* TemplateResource
* AWS::CloudFormation::Stack

Change-Id: I07ac22cc4370a79bd8712e2431fa3272115bc0eb
Co-Authored-By: Crag Wolfe <cwolfe@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1660831
"}, {'number': 24, 'created': '2017-06-28 02:55:57.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/attributes.py', 'heat/engine/sync_point.py', 'heat/engine/resources/template_resource.py', 'heat/engine/resource.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/45e4c53f78a2211c615b1e37bd86dacc815fb388', 'message': "Cache attributes with custom handling

Previously, all caching of attribute values was done via the Attributes
object. However, some resource types override Resource.get_attribute() to
do custom handling of the trailing attribute path or dynamic attribute
names, and in these cases the resulting values were not cached (since they
don't go through the Attributes object).

This patch adds a caching step for these resources:

* OS::Senlin::Cluster
* OS::Heat::ResourceChain
* OS::Heat::ResourceGroup
* OS::Heat::AutoscalingGroup
* OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment
* OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup
* TemplateResource
* AWS::CloudFormation::Stack

Change-Id: I07ac22cc4370a79bd8712e2431fa3272115bc0eb
Co-Authored-By: Crag Wolfe <cwolfe@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1660831
"}]
commit_message:
Cache attributes with custom handling

Previously, all caching of attribute values was done via the Attributes
object. However, some resource types override Resource.get_attribute() to
do custom handling of the trailing attribute path or dynamic attribute
names, and in these cases the resulting values were not cached (since they
don't go through the Attributes object).

This patch adds a caching step for these resources:

* OS::Senlin::Cluster
* OS::Heat::ResourceChain
* OS::Heat::ResourceGroup
* OS::Heat::AutoscalingGroup
* OS::Heat::SoftwareDeployment
* OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup
* TemplateResource
* AWS::CloudFormation::Stack

Change-Id: I07ac22cc4370a79bd8712e2431fa3272115bc0eb
Co-Authored-By: Crag Wolfe <cwolfe@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1660831

Block cmd2 0.7.3

cmd2 0.7.3 changes the method signature of cmd2.Cmd.complatenames
and it breaks cliff command completion feature.
This patch blocks cmd2 0.7.3.

commit_message:
use service type constants from neutron_lib plugins

The well known service type constants are in
neutron_lib.plugins.constants, but for legacy reasons a few still exist
and are referenced from neutron_lib.constants [1] that we'd like to
remove.

This patch switches references over to neutron_lib's plugin constants.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/constants.py#L353

Change-Id: Id22f2aefaa0c956d5116ffa43724f8a22c249c84
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/38/478238/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron_lib.plugins import constants as plugin_constants l3plugin = directory.get_plugin(plugin_constants.L3)

commit_message:
Pin erlang packages to version 19.3

Erlang 20 has been released and is not compatible with the current
release of RabbitMQ.[0] Pin erlang packages to the latest version
version supported by RabbitMQ 3.6.x, 19.3.

[0] https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/rabbitmq-users/_imbAavBYjY

Change-Id: Ia8f053e499db7aa7c78c60213d3154d967b92a98

commit_message:
[upstream] Add OUI Best Practices

This patch adds the best practices we have collected over the
last few trainings we have held. Its divided into three sections:
Tips for Trainers, Tips for the Class, and Tips for the Exercises.
It's linked to in the how to prepare section with a note that it's
for the trainers and not the students.

Change-Id: I0bc3fca1cbef255439d137d475b4470abe7cdaf7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/19/478319/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix some reST field lists in docstrings

Probably the most common format for documenting arguments is reST field
lists [1]. This change updates some docstrings to comply with the field
lists syntax.

[1] http://sphinx-doc.org/domains.html#info-field-lists

Change-Id: I0300dbac6dc02681cec2725b3c44a7dd1bfd7b4e

The plugin has been split into its own repository[1] in accordance with
Queens Goal "Split Tempest Plugins into Separate Repos/Projects[2]".

We can also now remove the autodoc_tree_excludes pbr option since
there's no more plugin to exclude and it defaults to [setup.py].

[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html

Queens Goal "Split Tempest Plugins into Separate Repos/Projects[2]".
This patch removes the local copy as well as the setuptools entry point.

commit_message:
Remove the local tempest plugin

The plugin has been split into its own repository[1] in accordance with
Queens Goal "Split Tempest Plugins into Separate Repos/Projects[2]".
This patch removes the local copy as well as the setuptools entry point.
We can also now remove the autodoc_tree_excludes pbr option since
there's no more plugin to exclude and it defaults to [setup.py].

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone-tempest-plugin
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html

Depends-On: I47f59505126509b6b52cf04b8f7501e8ef4041b7
Change-Id: I1805b196b42b6a76c56e129a316e170e767455c1

commit_message:
Remove Ubuntu Trusty 14.04 related code

Removed code try to install Wily(15.10) kernel in case of Ubuntu
Trusty(14.04).
Last Openstack version supported on Ubuntu 14.04 is Mitaka.
Hence Ubuntu 14.04 related code can be safely remove from Ansible tasks
since Kolla Newton release.

Co-Authored-By: Duong Ha-Quang <duonghq@vn.fujitsu.com>
Change-Id: Ieca7975a69fb0ba8b49cc522f05e4beca1c2f526

was changed and the new way is really simple. Let's use it.

commit_message:
Always create ResellerAdmin role for Swift

ResellerAdmin role should be created always when Swift is enabled
and not only for Ceilometer. The role is needed for normal users
to get administration rights for their Swift projects and is
required to pass DefCore (OpenStack Powered) certification.

Change-Id: I4faa63b8fae1814e382de2794301248cc0f4a90a
Closes-Bug: #1700729

commit_message:
Gate scripts: Update readme to describe multinode deployment

This PS updates the gate script to make multinode developer
deployment outside of zuul much clearer.

Change-Id: I25cc8c2f101dd0241d715ef7bf2e004cddf43c06
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/59/478359/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Supported Platforms ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Currently supported host platforms are: * Ubuntu 16.04 * CentOS 7 * Fedora 25 Usage (Single Node) ------------------- Usage (Multi Node) ------------------- To use for a multinode deployment you simply need to set a few extra environment variables: .. code:: bash export INTEGRATION=multi export INTEGRATION_TYPE=basic export PVC_BACKEND=ceph #IP of primary node: export PRIMARY_NODE_IP=1.2.3.4 #IP's of subnodes: export SUB_NODE_IPS="1.2.3.5 1.2.3.6 1.2.3.7" #Location of SSH private key to use with subnodes: export SSH_PRIVATE_KEY=/etc/nodepool/id_rsa ./tools/gate/setup_gate.sh Options ------------------- Rather than ceph, you may use a nfs based backend. This option is especially useful on old or low spec machines, though is not currently supported with Linux Kernels >=4.10: .. code:: bash export PVC_BACKEND=nfs
deleted_lines: Usage -----Supported Platforms ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Currently supported host platforms are: \* Ubuntu 16.04 \* CentOS 7 With some preparation to docker, and disabling of SELinux operation of Fedora 25 is also supported.

commit_message:
Support visualizing workload fingerprints

This spec describes the steps for visualizing a workload fingerprint.

Implements: bp workload-fingerprinting-fingerprint-visuzalization

Change-Id: I96e3f42f35d89a444ac911c7dc71c0723380b73c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher-specs refs/changes/94/448394/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================================================== Workload fingerprinting - Fingerprint Visualization. ==================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher-dashboard/+spec/workload-fingerprinting-fingerprint-visualization Workload fingerprint captures the behavior of a workload. A visual representation of the fingerprint makes it easy for a data center admin to understand overall workload behavior and use the same to potentially take resource management decisions. Problem description =================== A workload fingerprint generation audit that is completed successfully results in the workload.s fingerprint and the compute node.s model being stored into specific tables in the watcher database. The fingerprint consists of a phase transition probability matrix (n x n) and a phase residency matrix (n x 1), where n is the number of phases as configured for the fingerprint generation strategy. Both matrices contain positive real numbers, which are not easy to interpret, therefore the fingerprint must be visualized in an intuitive manner. The fingerprint plugin for the watcher dashboard provides this visualization. Use Cases ---------- A data center admin can see visualization of workload fingerprint strategy in the form of heatmap of transition probability matrix and residency array. A data center admin can also view the phase sequence graph, this helps in visualizing the phase sequence of each over a period of time. Project Priority ----------------- None Proposed change =============== * Add new panel is to watcher dashboard. * Add static files which includes css and js files for constructing heatmap and graphs for workload fingerprint strategy. * Add new template for workload fingerprint strategy into the current watcher dashboard templates. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Praveenraj R <praveenrajr9> Work Items ---------- Here is the list of foreseen work items: * Add new panel to the watcher dashboard, in in watcher-dashboard/watcher_dashboard/content/ * Include the workload fingerprint panel configuration for horizon dashboard in watcher-dashboard/watcher_dashboard/enabled * Add template consisting html files to support heatmap graph generation in watcher-dashboard/watcher_dashboard/templates/infra_optim/ * Add static files consisting of css and js files to support heatmap graph generation in watcher-dashboard/watcher_dashboard/static/infra_optim/ Dependencies ============ Watcher Workload Fingerprint Strategy Testing ======= The unit tests will have to be updated. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation must be updated to capture the functionalities of the newly added tab. References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ History ======= None

commit_message:
Fix regexes in published-schema.json

Id310567f2597cca136f51ae2b2bb464d76d96741 updated the service_type
regex in schema.json, but missed the corresponding changes for the
"forward" and "reverse" maps in published-schema.json.

Also corrects a typo in the regex for aliases, adding the end-of-string
anchor.

Change-Id: I2be09debedcc344d7859901341c39424d8904553

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/service-types-authority refs/changes/87/478287/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Each OpenStack service with a REST API must have a well known service type.- Match the regex ``^[a-z][a-z-]*[a-z]$``. As a special case, ``ec2-api`` is also allowed. - Meaningful (e.g. policy) - A thing, not an action (e.g. load-balancer, not load-balancing) - Singular instead of plural (e.g. image, not images) - Unversioned (e.g. volume, not volumev2)
deleted_lines: Each OpenStack Service with a REST API must have a well known service type.- Be matched by the regex ^[a-z][a-z-]+$ - Be meaningful (i.e. policy) - A thing, not an action (i.e. load-balancer, not load-balancing) - Singular instead of plural (i.e. image, not images) - Unversioned (volume, not volumev2)

commit_message:
Remove usage of parameter enforce_type

DeprecationWarning: Using the 'enforce_type' argument is deprecated in
version '4.0' and will be removed in version '5.0': The argument
enforce_type has changed its default value to True and then will be
removed completely."

Change-Id: I7901f858e4f79ab139055bf67eb01d8245430a49
See: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/328692/

subject: Refactor the Vitrage template content validators and their tests.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-26 15:11:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/vitrage/commit/2bc7d7a1e09ca33ab82a1ca5bb7e46c6b730018d', 'message': "Refactor the Vitrage template validators and their tests.

The motivations is that adding a new validator (e.g. for the new execute-mistral action) will be done in a separate and independent file.
As part of the refactoring, I moved the validation of the existence of the 'action_target' block from the syntax validator to the content validator, since in the execute-mistral action it won't be a mandatory field.

Change-Id: I97fe6d05e214e746f6129e3d18f805e830e21cf7
Implements: blueprint support-external-actions
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-06-27 10:31:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/vitrage/commit/af2d1823443c56466cbb4c3445a36cef20908514', 'message': "Refactor the Vitrage template content validators and their tests.

The motivations is that adding a new validator (e.g. for the new execute-mistral action) will be done in a separate and independent file.
As part of the refactoring, I moved the validation of the existence of the 'action_target' block from the syntax validator to the content validator, since in the execute-mistral action it won't be a mandatory field.

commit_message:
Refactor the Vitrage template content validators and their tests.

The motivations is that adding a new validator (e.g. for the new execute-mistral action) will be done in a separate and independent file.
As part of the refactoring, I moved the validation of the existence of the 'action_target' block from the syntax validator to the content validator, since in the execute-mistral action it won't be a mandatory field.

In the next change I will move template_content_validator and test_template_content_validator under the relevant 'content' packages. I removed it from this change since it caused git problems.

Change-Id: I97fe6d05e214e746f6129e3d18f805e830e21cf7
Implements: blueprint support-external-actions
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/72/477572/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid usingg
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I71c13040318eca6e5ed993e8aa03f8003986a71c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient refs/changes/81/430581/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for name, property in properties.items(): for setting, value in field_settings[field].items(): for k, v in d.items(): image = dict([item for item in image_obj.items()
deleted_lines: for name, property in six.iteritems(properties): for setting, value in six.iteritems(field_settings[field]): for k, v in six.iteritems(d): image = dict([item for item in six.iteritems(image_obj)

commit_message:
Create os-federation keystone ext client

Adds a new client lib to handle the OS-FEDERATION
identity v3 extension API.

Because the OS-FEDERATION API includes roughly
30 APIs, this patch only implements roughly half.
The rest will be added in a future patch.

This patch adds APIs, unit tests, and API tests for
the following OS-FEDERATION APIs:
  - create/list/update/show/delete for Identity
    Providers
  - create/list/update/show/delete for attribute
    mappings
  - create/list/update/show/delete for associating
    attribute mappings with Identity Providers

Further, this patch does not do thorough testing
for the domain_id kwarg related to Identity Providers,
since this kwarg was only recently added in Ocata [0]
and thus breaks backwards-compatibility if included
by default.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/399684/

Change-Id: I96fbcdf3902165aed0dcc197dc4da111091507c4

commit_message:
Fix html_last_updated_fmt for Python3

html_last_updated_fmt option is interpreted as a
byte string in python3, causing Sphinx build to break.
This patch makes it utf-8 string.

Change-Id: I8509f008fa97132f57d127070e7da5f4466391ae
Closes-Bug:#1693670

commit_message:
allow unhandled exceptions to cause test errors

Hiding the unhandled exception in the test with a failure makes it
harder to debug the problem. Let them pass unhandled so the test reports
an ERROR instead of FAILURE.

Change-Id: I4e435a6d276fdf161dac28f08c2c7efedd1d6385
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Split docker options and insecure registry

Use augeas to modify only parameters' dedicated configuration.
Split options from insecure registry. Overlapping those params may
unschedule the docker service restarts for some cases, ending up with
a split brain state for the docker service run-time config vs changed
/etc/sysconfig/options config.

Change-Id: Ic5640061837b022f7175f0db0dc269f9a61e6023
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/76/476476/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if $docker_options { $options_changes = [ "set OPTIONS '\"${docker_options}\"'" ] } else { $options_changes = [ 'rm OPTIONS' ] } augeas { 'docker-sysconfig-options': lens => 'Shellvars.lns', incl => '/etc/sysconfig/docker', changes => $options_changes, subscribe => Package['docker'], notify => Service['docker'], } $registry_changes = [ "set INSECURE_REGISTRY '\"--insecure-registry ${namespace}\"'" ] } else { $registry_changes = [ 'rm INSECURE_REGISTRY' ] } augeas { 'docker-sysconfig-registry': changes => $registry_changes,
deleted_lines: $changes = [ "set INSECURE_REGISTRY '\"--insecure-registry ${namespace}\"'", "set OPTIONS '\"${docker_options}\"'" ] } else { $changes = [ 'rm INSECURE_REGISTRY', "set OPTIONS '\"${docker_options}\"'" ] } augeas { 'docker-sysconfig': changes => $changes,

subject: [DNM] Wait for server deletion and list servers when over quota in tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-26 08:28:37.000000000', 'files': ['novaclient/tests/functional/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient/commit/5e020bebd2c35cecd5f8ab0260a788d3851ed829', 'message': "[DNM] Wait for server deletion and list servers when over quota in tests

Functional test runs have started randomly going over quota on the
number of instances, so things might not be getting cleaned up.

This change does two things:

1. Makes the server cleanup wait for the server to be gone.

2. If a server create fails with a 403, check to see if it's for
   going over quota on instances and then dump the list of instances
   before failing the test so we can maybe get an idea of the tests
   that are leaking.

Change-Id: Idaf42d2e1a620eb54c6ae4129c261366c755c64c
"}]
commit_message:
[DNM] Wait for server deletion and list servers when over quota in tests

Functional test runs have started randomly going over quota on the
number of instances, so things might not be getting cleaned up.

This change does two things:

1. Makes the server cleanup wait for the server to be gone.

2. If a server create fails with a 403, check to see if it's for
   going over quota on instances and then dump the list of instances
   before failing the test so we can maybe get an idea of the tests
   that are leaking.

Change-Id: Idaf42d2e1a620eb54c6ae4129c261366c755c64c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/46/477446/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sysfrom oslo_utils import excutilsimport sixfrom novaclient import exceptions try: server = self.client.servers.create(name, self.image, self.flavor, nics=nics, **kwargs) except exceptions.Forbidden as ex: # Check to see if we have gone over quota and if so, list the # resource to see what's leaking. with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): if 'Quota exceeded for instances' in six.text_type(ex): list_output = self.nova('list', merge_stderr=True) sys.stdout.write(list_output) sys.stdout.flush() quota_output = self.nova( 'quota-show', params='--detail', merge_stderr=True) sys.stdout.write(quota_output) sys.stdout.flush() if add_cleanup: self.addCleanup(self._cleanup_server, server.id)
deleted_lines: server = self.client.servers.create(name, self.image, self.flavor, nics=nics, **kwargs) if add_cleanup: self.addCleanup(server.delete)

commit_message:
Add missing deploy_composable_scenario variable

The "deploy_composable_scenario: true" variable was missing from our
scenario based featuresets, which was masked by an override in our
upstream testing, but results in missing the scenario files when trying
to reproduce them with the featureset configs only.

Change-Id: I7e7c13b9151607233f1159ed91c455dcec37e230

As we update the version information in the document, the ascii rst

Change-Id: I84aeba3604ced255b057b7ce43f1f94a1af19b65
'}]
commit_message:
Change the documentation table format

As we update the version information in the document, the ascii rst
table easily gets misaligned and causes the doc gate to fail.  This
patch set changes the table structure, while retaining the formatting,
so future update of the document can be done easily without spending
time realigning the table cell border.

Change-Id: I84aeba3604ced255b057b7ce43f1f94a1af19b65

commit_message:
Enable some off-by-default checks

Some of the available checks are disabled by default, like:
[H106] Don’t put vim configuration in source files
[H203] Use assertIs(Not)None to check for None

Change-Id: I2809ab2cce76dd31a04d3cca0e97cdad26c14cb4

commit_message:
use openstackdocstheme html context

Set some of the new config values and enable openstackdocstheme as an
extension so it will inject values into the page context as it writes
each documentation page. This ensures the pages link to the right bug
tracker, etc.

Change-Id: I36d400358b1b5e2c2423c43f43c775bafb0d4721
Depends-On: Icf3a40ed104cfd828f532f6f2b112ed02f996ff5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add image id to glance bootstrap for tempest test

This PS add glance image id to bootstrap, so we can make image
with predefined id for tempest test.

Change-Id: I061af4daa9574f87d82d68fcf3b7a3674436d3cf
Implements: blueprint specify-glance-image-id

commit_message:
Noisy Neighbor Strategy

Added strategy to identify and migrate a Noisy Neighbor - a low priority VM
that negatively affects peformance of a high priority VM by over utilizing
Last Level Cache.

Partially Implements: blueprint noisy-neighbor-strategy

Change-Id: Ia13f7e91a695024410b8f3b3d3d1646a0dd687d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher refs/changes/59/454359/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- encoding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright (c) 2017 Intel Corp # # Authors: Prudhvi Rao Shedimbi <prudhvi.rao.shedimbi@intel.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # from oslo_log import log from watcher._i18n import _, _LW, _LI from watcher.common import exception as wexc from watcher.datasource import ceilometer as ceil from watcher.decision_engine.strategy.strategies import base LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class NoisyNeighbor(base.NoisyNeighborBaseStrategy): MIGRATION = "migrate" # The meter to report L3 cache in ceilometer METER_NAME_L3 = "cpu_l3_cache" # The meter to report cumulative processor instructions of VM in ceilometer METER_NAME_INSTRUCTIONS = "perf.instructions" # The meter to report cumulative cpu cycles of a VM in ceilometer METER_NAME_CPU_CYCLES = "perf.cpu.cycles" # choose 300 seconds as the default duration of meter aggregation PERIOD = 300 def __init__(self, config, osc=None): """Noisy Neighbor strategy using live migration :param config: A mapping containing the configuration of this strategy :type config: dict :param osc: an OpenStackClients object, defaults to None :type osc: :py:class:`~.OpenStackClients` instance, optional """ super(NoisyNeighbor, self).__init__(config, osc) # The migration plan will be triggered when the airflow reaches # threshold self.meter_name_l3 = self.METER_NAME_L3 self.meter_name_instructions = self.METER_NAME_INSTRUCTIONS self.meter_name_cpu_cycles = self.METER_NAME_CPU_CYCLES self._ceilometer = None self._period = self.PERIOD @property def ceilometer(self): if self._ceilometer is None: self._ceilometer = ceil.CeilometerHelper(osc=self.osc) return self._ceilometer @ceilometer.setter def ceilometer(self, c): self._ceilometer = c @classmethod def get_name(cls): return "noisy_neighbor" @classmethod def get_display_name(cls): return _("Noisy Neighbor") @classmethod def get_translatable_display_name(cls): return "Noisy Neighbor" @classmethod def get_schema(cls): # Mandatory default setting for each element return { "properties": { "cache_threshold": { "description": "Performance drop in L3_cache threshold " "for migration", "type": "number", "default": 35.0 }, "ipc_threshold": { "description": "Performance drop in IPC threshold for " "migration", "type": "number", "default": 15.0 }, }, } def find_priority_and_noisy_instances(self): nodes = self.compute_model.get_all_compute_nodes() size_cluster = len(nodes) if size_cluster == 0: raise wexc.ClusterEmpty() hosts_need_release = {} hosts_target = [] for node in nodes.values(): instances_of_node = self.compute_model.get_node_instances(node) node_instance_count = len(instances_of_node) break_flag = 0 if node_instance_count > 1: instance_priority_list = [] for instance in instances_of_node: instance_priority_list.append(instance) instance_priority_list.sort(key=lambda a: a.metadata[ 'watcher-priority']) instance_priority_list_reverse = list(instance_priority_list) instance_priority_list_reverse.reverse() for potential_priority_instance in instance_priority_list: instructions_1 = \ self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_instructions, period=100, aggregate='avg') instructions_2 = 2 * ( self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_instructions, period=200, aggregate='avg')) - \ instructions_1 instructions_3 = 3 * ( self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_instructions, period=300, aggregate='avg')) - \ instructions_1 - instructions_2 cpu_cycles_1 = \ self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_cpu_cycles, period=100, aggregate='avg') cpu_cycles_2 = 2 * ( self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_cpu_cycles, period=200, aggregate='avg')) - cpu_cycles_1 cpu_cycles_3 = 3 * ( self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_cpu_cycles, period=300, aggregate='avg')) - \ (cpu_cycles_1 + cpu_cycles_2) if None in ( instructions_1, instructions_2, instructions_3, cpu_cycles_1, cpu_cycles_2, cpu_cycles_3): LOG.warning(_LW("Ceilometer unable to pick L3 Cache " "or IPC values. Skipping the node")) break instructions_diff_1 = instructions_1 - instructions_2 instructions_diff_2 = instructions_2 - instructions_3 cpu_cycles_diff_1 = cpu_cycles_1 - cpu_cycles_2 cpu_cycles_diff_2 = cpu_cycles_2 - cpu_cycles_3 current_ipc = instructions_diff_1 / cpu_cycles_diff_1 previous_ipc = instructions_diff_2 / cpu_cycles_diff_2 current_cache = self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_l3, period=100, aggregate='avg') previous_cache = 2 * ( self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_priority_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_l3, period=200, aggregate='avg')) - current_cache if None in (current_cache, previous_cache): LOG.warning(_LW("Ceilometer unable to pick L3 Cache " "or IPC values. Skipping the node")) break if (current_ipc < (1 - (self.ipc_threshold / 100)) * previous_ipc and current_cache < ( 1 - (self.cache_threshold / 100)) * previous_cache): for potential_noisy_instance in \ instance_priority_list_reverse: if(potential_noisy_instance == potential_priority_instance): break noisy_current_cache = \ self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_noisy_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_l3, period=100, aggregate='avg') noisy_prev_cache = 2 * ( self.ceilometer.statistic_aggregation( resource_id=potential_noisy_instance.uuid, meter_name=self.meter_name_l3, period=200, aggregate='avg')) - \ noisy_current_cache if None in (noisy_current_cache, noisy_prev_cache): LOG.warning(_LW("Ceilometer unable to pick " "L3 Cache or IPC values. " "Skipping the node")) break_flag = 1 break # This is where we decide if this is noisy vm. Can # change 30 to any other value. # Still deciding whether to take it as a param # from user. if (noisy_current_cache > (1 + (30 / 100) * noisy_prev_cache)): hosts_need_release[node] = { 'priority_vm': potential_priority_instance, 'noisy_vm': potential_noisy_instance} LOG.debug("Priority VM found: %s" % ( potential_priority_instance.uuid)) LOG.debug("Noisy VM found: %s" % ( potential_noisy_instance.uuid)) break_flag = 1 break if break_flag == 1: break if node not in hosts_need_release: hosts_target.append(node) return hosts_need_release, hosts_target def calc_used_resource(self, node): """Calculate the used vcpus, memory and disk based on VM flavors""" instances = self.compute_model.get_node_instances(node) vcpus_used = 0 memory_mb_used = 0 disk_gb_used = 0 for instance in instances: vcpus_used += instance.vcpus memory_mb_used += instance.memory disk_gb_used += instance.disk return vcpus_used, memory_mb_used, disk_gb_used def filter_dest_servers(self, hosts, instance_to_migrate): required_cores = instance_to_migrate.vcpus required_disk = instance_to_migrate.disk required_memory = instance_to_migrate.memory dest_servers = [] for host in hosts: cores_used, mem_used, disk_used = self.calc_used_resource(host) cores_available = host.vcpus - cores_used disk_available = host.disk - disk_used mem_available = host.memory - mem_used if cores_available >= required_cores and disk_available >= \ required_disk and mem_available >= required_memory: dest_servers.append(host) return dest_servers def pre_execute(self): LOG.debug("Initializing Noisy Neighbor strategy") if not self.compute_model: raise wexc.ClusterStateNotDefined() if self.compute_model.stale: raise wexc.ClusterStateStale() LOG.debug(self.compute_model.to_string()) def do_execute(self): self.cache_threshold = self.input_parameters.cache_threshold self.ipc_threshold = self.input_parameters.ipc_threshold LOG.debug("Initializing Noisy Neighbor strategy") hosts_need_release, hosts_target = \ self.find_priority_and_noisy_instances() if len(hosts_need_release) == 0: LOG.debug("No hosts require optimization") return self.solution if len(hosts_target) == 0: LOG.debug("No hosts available to migrate") mig_source_node = max(hosts_need_release.iterkeys(), key=lambda a: hosts_need_release[a]['priority_vm']) instance_to_migrate = hosts_need_release[mig_source_node]['noisy_vm'] if instance_to_migrate is None: return self.solution dest_servers = self.filter_dest_servers(hosts_target, instance_to_migrate) if len(dest_servers) == 0: LOG.info(_LI("No proper target host could be found")) return self.solution mig_destination_node = dest_servers[0] if self.compute_model.migrate_instance(instance_to_migrate, mig_source_node, mig_destination_node): parameters = {'migration_type': 'live', 'source_node': mig_source_node.uuid, 'destination_node': mig_destination_node.uuid} self.solution.add_action(action_type=self.MIGRATION, resource_id=instance_to_migrate.uuid, input_parameters=parameters) def post_execute(self): self.solution.model = self.compute_model LOG.debug(self.compute_model.to_string())

commit_message:
Replace assertRaisesRegexp with assertRaisesRegex

assertRaisesRegexp was renamed to assertRaisesRegex in Py3.2
For more details, please check:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/
unittest.html#unittest.TestCase.assertRaisesRegex

Change-Id: Ied395e2c7bff32a4108ac3194f88249e0f2a1760
Closes-Bug: #1436957
